subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Utter/Ado
msgSnippet: Another possibility is to explicitly assign /V/ and /@/ to the two forms of #36, which I will refer to as original utter and alternative utter . Now, which
messageBody:
Another possibility is to explicitly assign /V/ and /@/ to the two
forms of #36, which I will refer to as 'original utter' and
'alternative utter'. Now, which should be which? I suggest assigning
'original utter' to /V/ and 'alternative utter' to /@/.

I'd like to keep 'original utter' for the stressed vowel because it's
the primary form in the original alphabet. The alternative was only
introduced in the QM for convenience in connecting to subsequent
letters, and the only one of these that I've included in preliminary
sketches for my font is #36+#24 (which I call 'Ultra').

Under this proposal, I don't see any way to avoid promoting the symbol
for 'alternative utter' to full membership in the alphabet. For now
I'm calling it #36 1/2, with the idea that the most natural thing to
do is to put it immediately after #36 and bump the remaining letters
over one position. I'd also like to swap Jon Zuck's names, calling #36
'Up' and #36 1/2 'Ado' to reflect stress.

I think it's best to continue to use 'original utter' in the ligature
of #36+#25. This does lead naturally to the question (already under
discussion) of whether this ligature should be considered a letter in
it's own right. That question is complicated by the fact that there
are other ligatures such as #33+#25 which would also be candidates for
letter-hood. This is a bit of a quandry since it seems to me that the
larger the alphabet, the more intimidating it is for beginners.

I've updated this document to reflect these ideas:
http://staff.washington.edu/freeman/qs/qs_proposal2.pdf

(Comments on the choices of ligatures to include in a new font, and
their names and keyboard assignments are welcome!)

Thanks.

Ted


On Nov 21, 2007 3:26 AM, Anthony Grahn <othermale@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
> >
> >Anthony also suggests we should create a solution to deal with Ado,
> >which is already overburdened. So he seems to be trying to work things
> >out in a very helpful way.
> >
>
> That and I live in GMT+1 so I can't really contribute in your afternoon.
>
> So as I understand it Utter fills the following roles:
>
> 1. The unstressed indefinite vowel. For which we assigned the set
> COMMA to Utter
> 2. The /V/ sound for which we assigned it STRUT
> 3. When combined with Roe, it shares the /3/ sound. That is to say for
> the "ligature" Utter+Roe we assigned the lexical set NURSE
>
> 1. COMMA
> Do not use the letter Utter for COMMA. Indeed do not have any letter
> represent the indefinite vowel. Instead write the letter for the
> sound the vowel has when it is stressed in that same root. Write the
> "mental image" of the sound as it were. (sometimes of course this
> turns out to be /V/ in which case one will use Utter after all (see
> below))
>
> - This has some whopping great advantages for morphemic writing: many
> roots will no longer vary when suffixes are added:
> e.g.
> with the old approach we had:
> photography, photograph, photographer
> Fee+Owe+Tea+Ox+Gay+Roe...
> Fee+Owe+Tea+UTTER+Gay+Roe...
> Fee+Owe+Tea+Ox+Gay+Roe...
> which very much damages readability compared to TO
> But under the news system this and many other roots will be spelled
> the same no mater the affixes.
>
> -It might actually be easier for writers to do this rather than
> carefully notice the indefinite version of the vowel they are writing.
>
> -When writers make mistakes I think it will mean inserting Utter which
> is the same as the old system anyway.
>
> -It does not fly in the face of the QM too very much
>
> Having said all that I must say I still have reservations because we
> can not test it out properly. In order to do so would need countless
> users to try to write using this rule and see if in fact it works.
>
> 2. STRUT
> Utter is still used for STRUT and it becomes its sole role.
>
> 3. NURSE
> Take NURSE away from the Utter+Roe combination. It is not the sound
> the separate letters make and while it's close enough for us rhotics,
> it is untenable to ask non-rhotics to use the same symbol (Utter+Roe
> ligature) for /3/ and /Vr/ (e.g. "arrest" vs "nurse")
>
> So this then leaves the question of where to put NURSE instead. I'd
> really strongly discourage adding a truly new letter under all
> circumstances, it is an utterly immense undertaking. So we would
> assign it to an existing letter and I would say that Roe works fine.
>
> Thus: make Roe cover /r/ *and* the lexical set NURSE (which implies /3/ )
>
> -This trick worked for Ing, Read himself used it there (although we
> expanded it a tad)
>
> -The problem with the Utter-Roe "ligature" goes away. And if all other
> Roe ligature problems can be accounted for with that "Et/Eight, It/Eat
> , Foot/Ooze neutralization before Roe" law. We have solved it all.
>
> -"arrest" is spelled Utter-Roe-Et-Sea-Tea. "nurse" is spelled
> No-Roe-Sea. We already had "being" as Bay-Ing and "king" was now
> Key-Ing so it shouldn't be too shocking.
>
> My only concern is that this may be trouble for accents that strongly
> roll their Rs; a rolled r is very different than /3/ and could be too
> much to ask of them to use one letter for both. But as a humorous
> aside we will now be able to directly transliterate
> Croatian place names like "Krk"
>
>
